text:
ANDREW WINSTON:
So there's always

this assumption in
sustainability and climate

action that it will
be more expensive.

And I think it's an overly
simplified question.

Some things you do to
reduce emissions save money
very quickly--

a lighting retrofit in
a building, in cities.

That's happening all
over the place now.
It pays back very, very fast.

Going to renewable energy
now is actually cheaper.
It didn't used to be.

So people ask, well,
how can we go green?

Or how can we cut emissions,
because it will cost more?
It doesn't, first of all.

I mean, a lot of
the pathways don't.

There might be choices we
make for long term investment

to change the way our supply
chain works, the way we make

something in a
fundamental way, or how

it works for consumers
and customers
to reduce their footprint.

That might take R&D. That
might take innovation,
but that's investment, not cost.

We always get caught in
this strange semantics

about if it's for
sustainability, it's a cost.

But everything in
business is a cost.
It's an investment.

You invest in
marketing, R&D, people.

This is an investment,
and it's a smart one now,

to build a thriving
society that's low carbon.
